pageContext.description: Hilt broken off through rivet hole. Blade broken near point + roughly mended. Edge chipped near fracture. Point slightly filed.
pageContext.patina: Reddish brown patina rubbed off in places.
pageContext.surface: Slightly pitted in one or two places.
pageContext.publications: Rdt. Kingon, Shrops. Arch. Trans., IV (2ns Series, 1892), 280,Anden, Vic. Co. Hist. Shrops, I, 202, (under "Bagley"),"Times", 14th March 1921
pageContext.collection: Ellesmere Museum,Pres. by W. Nugent Monck, 1920
pageContext.site: England,Shropshire,Ellesmere,Val Hill in the township of Tetchill,found by a workman while grubbing up a fence
pageContext.remarks: The sword seems to have been broken by the workmen who found it. It was taken to the Rev. Walter Moore, Rector of Hordley, who had it mended by the Hordley Blacksmith, who was probably responsible for filing the point. From the Rev. Walter Moore, it passed into the hands of his son, Mr. Charles Moore, of the Hollies Ellesmere, at whose death it was given to the Ellesmere Museum by his executor.
